repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
Headings in :help do not stand out visually.

Solution:
Define a non-standard `@markup.heading.1.delimiter` group and special-case it in `highlight_group.c`.

FUTURE:
This is a cheap workaround until we have https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25718 which will enable:
- fully driven by `vimdoc/highlights.scm` instead of using highlight tricks (`guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg`)
- better support of "cterm" ('notermguicolors')



Before/After:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e93ff856-c9c7-438c-8431-379991373026)

comment_data.body: Any reason not to use the Lua highlight API here?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,7 +1,13 @@
 -- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
 vim.treesitter.start()
 
--- add custom highlights for list in `:h highlight-groups`
+-- Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+vim.cmd[[

comment_data.body: Any reason you're not simply using `@markup.heading.1.delimiter.vimdoc`, which would be the documented approach instead of a custom "hack"?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,7 +1,13 @@
 -- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
 vim.treesitter.start()
 
--- add custom highlights for list in `:h highlight-groups`
+-- Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+vim.cmd[[
+  hi @markup.heading.delimiter1.vimdoc guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underdouble

comment_data.body:
(I used to have the `.delimiter` groups but removed them due to pressure. If we really want to make use of them, we should officially reintroduce and document them (and use them also in markdown etc.; would be a lot of extra work for me in nvim-treesitter, though...) 

As they are part of the fallback hierarchy, they would work gracefully.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,7 +1,13 @@
 -- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
 vim.treesitter.start()
 
--- add custom highlights for list in `:h highlight-groups`
+-- Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+vim.cmd[[
+  hi @markup.heading.delimiter1.vimdoc guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underdouble

comment_data.body: Or just define these highlight groups in the default scheme?

> Or just define these highlight groups in the default scheme?

didn't know about `@markup.heading.1.delimiter.vimdoc` , thanks

> Any reason not to use the Lua highlight API here?

more verbose. someone else can do that if they want

@@ -1,7 +1,13 @@

--- add custom highlights for list in `:h highlight-groups`

comment_data.body: Did not specify `.vimdoc` here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -301,6 +301,11 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link @tag         Tag",
   "default link @tag.builtin Special",
 
+  // Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+  // This is for :help but also presumably useful for markdown etc.
+  "default @markup.heading.1.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underdouble,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underdouble,nocombine",
+  "default @markup.heading.2.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underline,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underline,nocombine",

comment_data.body:
Also for markdown headings. Can revert this commit if wanted, but maybe let it bake on master to get hate mail first. It does make editing the heading a bit surprising, but not unreasonable.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7a3a272d-6534-4dfb-826a-d6d5b6bc97d3)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,11 +1,11 @@
 ;From MDeiml/tree-sitter-markdown & Helix
 (setext_heading
   (paragraph) @markup.heading.1
-  (setext_h1_underline) @markup.heading.1)
+  (setext_h1_underline) @markup.heading.1.delimiter)
 
 (setext_heading
   (paragraph) @markup.heading.2
-  (setext_h2_underline) @markup.heading.2)
+  (setext_h2_underline) @markup.heading.2.delimiter)

comment_data.body:
(Sorry, missed the Markdown change here.)

I have to admit I'm not happy about diverging from nvim-treesitter here (especially for Markdown) since this will make syncing changes harder.

Consider introducing these as official highlight groups so I can backport the changes.

   "default link @tag.builtin Special",

comment_data.body:
I'm confused, I thought https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/30544#discussion_r1778611134 indicated that `@markup.heading.1.delimiter.vimdoc` was the standard?

What are we diverging from? Is `@markup.heading.2.delimiter` a new group?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -301,6 +301,11 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link @tag         Tag",
   "default link @tag.builtin Special",
 
+  // Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+  // This is for :help but also presumably useful for markdown etc.
+  "default @markup.heading.1.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underdouble,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underdouble,nocombine",
+  "default @markup.heading.2.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underline,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underline,nocombine",

comment_data.body:
Yes, but one that plays relatively nicely with the existing groups (unlike other permutations).

As I wrote above, we used to have separate `heading.delimiter` groups but removed them during the standardization (here). As nvim-treesitter queries are validated against the standard list, we cannot use undocumented captures there.

This is most an issue for Markdown, which is used widely; since we can claim to "own" vimdoc, we have a bit more leeway there for deviating from "upstream". So I would be less concerned if this was limited to vimdoc (for now).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -301,6 +301,11 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link @tag         Tag",
   "default link @tag.builtin Special",
 
+  // Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.
+  // This is for :help but also presumably useful for markdown etc.
+  "default @markup.heading.1.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underdouble,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underdouble,nocombine",
+  "default @markup.heading.2.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underline,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underline,nocombine",

comment_data.body:
To be clear, the issues here are:
* We can't include these queries in nvim-treesitter without adding the captures to `:h treesitter-highlight-groups`.
* If we do, we need to use them consistently.
* Adding the (generic) `@markup.heading.X.delimiter` highlight group will not work for some Markdown (and other markup) delimiters.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -301,6 +301,11 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {
   "default link @tag         Tag",
   "default link @tag.builtin Special",
 
+  // Higlight "===" and "---" heading delimiters specially.

+  "default @markup.heading.2.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underline,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underline,nocombine",

comment_data.body: Looks nice, but I would indeed prefer to keep Markdown out of it (for now); the potential impact is too wide. Keeping this focused on vimdoc would be much more manageable (and a clearer improvement).
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-  (setext_h2_underline) @markup.heading.2)
+  (setext_h2_underline) @markup.heading.2.delimiter)

comment_data.body:
Got it. I'll revert the markdown commit, it's not very high-value (until we have https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25718 ).

I'm happy to update the standard groups, but maybe this group will be unnecessary after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25718 , because we can use queries instead of highlight tricks?

+  "default @markup.heading.2.delimiter guibg=bg guifg=bg guisp=fg gui=underline,nocombine ctermbg=NONE ctermfg=NONE cterm=underline,nocombine",

comment_data.body:
> I'm happy to update the standard delimiters, but maybe this group will be unnecessary after https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25718 , because we can use queries instead of highlight tricks?

Yes, exactly. And if we limit this to vimdoc for now, we can keep it internal. (Maybe add a simple screentest, though, to make sure I don't accidentally regress when syncing queries...)

comment_data.body: added test
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -894,9 +894,45 @@ describe('treesitter highlighting (help)', function()
       [3] = { bold = true, foreground = Screen.colors.Brown },
       [4] = { foreground = Screen.colors.Cyan4 },
       [5] = { foreground = Screen.colors.Magenta1 },
+      title = { bold = true, foreground = Screen.colors.Magenta1 },
+      h1_delim = { nocombine = true, underdouble = true },
+      h2_delim = { nocombine = true, underline = true },
     }
   end)
 
+  it('defaults in vimdoc/highlights.scm', function()
+    -- Avoid regressions when syncing upstream vimdoc queries.

comment_data.body:
One issue I see with this is that this will not play nicely with other colorschemes since the `guisp` is hard-coded (and likely different from the `@markup.heading.1` group).

(And since it's a "secret" highlight group, colorschemes will not override it.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -301,6 +301,11 @@ static const char *highlight_init_both[] = {

   "default link @tag.builtin Special",


> since the `guisp` is hard-coded

how is it any more "hard coded" than any other `default` highlight attribute?

comment_regular_data.body: Am I missing something here? Wouldn't that still show the `-` and `=` characters, which seem to be missing from your screenshots?
Should also add a todo about #25718, which will allow this to work without hacks and custom highlight groups.

> Wouldn't that still show the `-` and `=` characters, which seem to be missing from your screenshots?

No because `guibg=bg guifg=bg` hides those, while `guisp` is used for the underline.

Doesn't seem to work with 'notermguicolors' though.

> No because guibg=bg guifg=bg hides those, while guisp is used for the underline.

Ah, I see. I was expecting a `conceal` here, which...

> Doesn't seem to work with 'notermguicolors' though.

should also work in this case. (Or adding them to the -- four -- default schemes.)

labels.description: issues or PRs involving changing the defaults
labels.name: defaults

title: feat(defaults): pretty :help headings
